content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government Appropriations, 2001. Prior to this, P.L. 106-275 provided funding for most Treasury and General Government accounts at the FY2000 level. Additionally, P.L. 106-346 partially funded select accounts from the primary funding measure. Various measures were considered before the enactment of P.L. 106-554. Several measures were enacted to fund affected accounts, including House bill H.R. 4871, Senate bill S. 2900, and Legislative Branch Appropriation H.R. 4516/H.R. 4985. Transportation Appropriations P.L. 106-346 provided partial funding, while FY2001 Continuing Funding Resolution P.L. 106-275 and P.L. 106-426 authorized funding for the presidential transition. The bulk of accounts were funded through P.L. 106-554, with supplemental funding from P.L. 106-346. The Executive Office of the President, Postal Service, and General Government FY2001 are funded through P.L.106-554 (H.R. 4577/H.R. 5658). P.L. 106-346 provides supplemental funding for certain accounts. The President submits the Budget of the United States Government annually to Congress. Congress passes a concurrent resolution establishing the congressional budget and allocates discretionary funding levels to subcommittees. A budget resolution is a concurrent resolution passed by Congress setting forth the budget for at least the next five fiscal years. A continuing resolution provides temporary budget authority to agencies or programs when regular appropriations have not been enacted. A continuing resolution is a temporary measure that provides budget authority to agencies or programs when regular appropriations have not been enacted. It can expire on a specified date or be superseded by the regular appropriations act. Direct spending refers to budget authority provided in laws other than annual appropriations acts, while discretionary spending is provided in annual appropriations acts. Federal funds encompass all money collected and spent by the federal government, excluding trust funds. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, is subject to specific rules and includes appropriated entitlements. Obligations are binding agreements requiring payment, while outlays are payments made to liquidate obligations. The reconciliation process aligns tax and spending levels with the budget resolution by changing existing laws. Revolving funds use income from operations to finance ongoing expenses without fiscal year limitations. Scorekeeping tracks congressional budget actions, while supplemental appropriations provide additional budget authority.
